review.title: Plausibility and probability in deductive reasoning
review.abstract: We consider the problem of rational uncertainty about unproven mathematical statements, which G\"odel and others have remarked on. Using Bayesian-inspired arguments we build a normative model of fair bets under deductive uncertainty which diverges from probability theory per se but draws on the theory of algorithms. We comment on connections to Zeilberger's notion of "semi-rigorous proofs", particularly that inherent subjectivity is an obstacle.

sections.heading: 1 A natural problem: Quantified deductive uncertainty 2
1.1 The phenomenon
sections.text: If we have an algorithm and it is usually told a practical time, then we mean facts that we observe from the outside world. For example, whether it rains tomorrow is a piece of information that we have not observed, so we are uncertain about its truth value. However, we may also have uncertainty about purely deductive statements that are completely determined by the information we have, due to limited reasoning ability. That is, before we have proven or refuted a mathematical statement, we have a certain deductive uncertainty about whether there is a proof or a refutation. Under deductive uncertainty, there is a familiar process of evaluating a degree of faith in one way or another that a statement has a high or low plausibility. We can express rough confidence levels in notable open assumptions such as P 6 = NP [21] or the Goldbach conjecture, and we also deal with plausibility in everyday mathematical thinking. Sometimes, general patterns show up about problems and we raise them to new levels.

sections.heading: 1.2 The (modeling) problem
sections.text: It is easy to give examples of general statements about integers in which the probability itself can be estimated. For example, the probability of the proposition stating that there is at least one digit 6 for each uncertainty is higher than for any other digit. However, one can be unsure whether it makes sense to ask what the probability of this general statement is, how to do it for a greater and greater probability. Boolos, of course, asks how such probabilities are calculated [4]: However, one can be unsure whether it makes sense to ask what the probability is for this general statement, since it has not been falsified under n = 1000000, or whether it exceeds the probability. With Boolos, we want to know how subjective deductive probabilities generally work? Do they even make sense to assign these probabilities? Do they have any sense at all?

sections.heading: 2.1.1 Plausibility functions
sections.text: Fix an encoding of deductive statements into finite strings so that there is a decision problem that corresponds to the true statements. We take an assignment of plausibility to encrypted statements as a function p: {0, 1} к → [0, 1]. We call p a plausibility function. A plausibility function represents the uncertainty of an agent about it. One could also have defined a plausibility function to take a finite sequence of input strings and return a finite sequence of plausibility, that is, to work at the level of betting systems, rather than betting.

sections.heading: 2.1.2 Languages
sections.text: Finding evidence is a matter of calculation, so our thinking skills are equivalent to our computational resources, and in general we will experience deductive uncertainty when faced with an insoluble arithmetic problem. Importantly, we cannot meaningfully talk about problems with only one input, since the best output is obviously the actual truth value. Thus, we must speak of uncertainty over a whole series of inputs at the same time. Probability spaces consist of a measurable space and a measure of probability. In Bayesianism, measurable space can be replaced by a "propositional space" closed under logical operations. In the deductive case, each non-trivial problem has an input set that is trivially closed under logical operations, as each input is logically equivalent to "true" or "false." We come to the conclusion that the problem does not require a special syntactical structure and that we consider standard problems from theoretical computer science.

sections.heading: 2.1.4 Conditional plausibility
sections.text: If we select plausibility functions by optimizing them by means of practicable functions, the definition of feasibility may change over time or simply vary from context to context, so that we generally speak of conditional plausibility functions p (· | S), where S is an oracle or a complexity class or another representation of the resources available to calculate the function. Another interpretation is that the cost of calculation can effectively decrease over time, increasing the budget set of feasible functions. This notation and terminology point to an analogy in which knowledge in the sense of calculation (such as that of [15, Sec. 9.2.3, 16, Sec. 7.2]) takes the place of information. In full generality, an agent may have an internal state that influences the calculated plausibility function. Specifically, this means that over the life of the agent it performs background calculations that are added to a "growing knowledge base" by adding a greater later functionality.

sections.heading: 2.2.1 On bets and scoring rules
sections.text: In fair bets, we implicitly assume a linear benefit in money, but we can at least refute the assumption: First, we find the benefit of the agent's money in lotteries, then we scale monetary units to have a linear relationship to benefit. Betting decisions must include the chance to buy, sell, or do nothing; only the choice between buy and nothing allows p + 0 to mean no bets at all. Bets must be finite, otherwise the analysis is trivial. It is possible that a betting event itself contains new knowledge to which we should update prior to betting. This would be the case if the party offering the bet is known to have access to a powerful oracle. For operational purposes, we consider situations where we do not update the bet itself; for example, if the bidding party is known to be stupid or not self-determined. sections.heading: 3.1 Foundations of “semi-rigorous proofs”
sections.text: Zeilberger presented the concept of a "semi-rigorous proof" and predicted that it could become acceptable to the mathematical community: "I can imagine an abstraction of a paper, circa 2100, which reads:" We show in a certain precise sense that the Goldbach assumption is likely to be more than 0.99999 'true. "[42] For such a result to be useful, there must be cases in which plausibility is objective or subjective? Should we expect people to agree on plausibility? There are various sources of subjectivity: How can one embed individual questions into problems, first order logical problems, and problems that are mathematically difficult to assess so that plausibility is objective or subjective? Should we expect people to agree on plausibility? There are various sources of subjectivity: How can one embed individual questions into problems, logical problems of first order, are subjective problems, and if these problems are logical and correct problems?

sections.heading: 3.2 Logical omniscience in Bayesian epistemology
sections.text: Even within traditional Bayesianism, the assumption of numerical limitlessness may be undesirable; this is known as the problem of logical omniscience [20, 22, 40]. Some work has been done on formal models of logical non-omniscience, including a resource-limited AIXI [23] and resource-limited Solomonoff before [27]. Even the approximate inference in Bayesian networks is NP-hard, although there is research on methods such as faith propagation that is successful in particular cases. The general problem remains, at least in the following form. Solomonoff's recursion theory notion of extrapolation [24, 27] gives an ideal family of "universal" previous distributions that are suitable for general agents. However, there is no useful relationship of improvement on approximations, since there is only one ideal that is unpredictable, and no guidance on how best to approach it.

sections.heading: 3.3 Decision theory
sections.text: It is not clear what relationship plausibility should have with a more general decision theory. Even with physical or deductive uncertainty, the expected benefit maximization needs to be modified in the case of limited agents, since tasks other than assigning plausibility can also be difficult in arithmetical terms. Consistency is a common assumption that allows simple decisions about bets and usefulness to determine arbitrarily complex decisions. In the face of arithmetic problems that can only be approximated by an actual agent, such as integration or optimization, this kind of consistency is not feasible. Therefore, repealing a theory of bets to a theory of general decisions also involves taking into account arithmetic solutions for the various problems involved in more general decisions. Our approach here could already include important parts and concepts for a more general theory. Models of deductive uncertainty based on formal logic are associated with applications of Yaney intelligence [38], artificial sky, [39] and [39] the present sky.
